Key words.Definitions: a high-speed point-to-point channel for attaching a video card to a computer’s motherboard, primarily to assist in the acceleration of 3D computer graphics.

Digital technologies that help drivers in routine navigation and parking without fully automating the entire process but instead leveraging computer networks to enable more data-driven and safer driving experiences.
a microprocessor, ASIC or expansion card designed to offload a specific task from the CPU, often containing fixed function hardware; a common example is a Graphics processing unit.
a register in a CPU in which intermediate arithmetic and logic results are stored.
A combinational digital circuit that performs arithmetic and bitwise operations on binary numbers.
Short for accelerated processing unit or advanced processing unit, APU is any processing that happens outside of the computer's CPU.
A family of reduced instruction set computing (RISC) architectures for computer processors, which prioritize simplicity and efficiency.
the smallest unit of data that a computer can process.
a subsystem that transfers data between computer components inside a computer or between computers.
A method of interacting with an application, typically hosted on a remote device, via controls presented within a web browser.
A unit of data that is eight binary digits long.
a small, fast local memory that transparently buffers access to a larger but slower or more distant/higher latency memory or storage device, organised into cache lines.
a small block of memory within a cache; the granularity of allocation,refills,eviction; typically 32-128 bytes in size.
Supplementary memory system that temporarily stores frequently used instructions and data for quicker processing by the central processing unit (CPU) of a computer.
A small piece of electrical hardware that can hold electrical energy within a circuit or field.
the portion of a computer system that executes the instructions of a computer program.
a pre-pressed optical compact disc which contains data or music playback.
A writable disc upon which a user can write. once and read many times.
A digital optical disc storage format. A CD-RW compact disc (CD-RWs) can be written, read, erased, and re-written.
A model of computation in which input values proceed through a sequence of gates, each of which computes a function.
an electronic device that manipulates information, or data. It has the ability to store, retrieve, and process data.

A computer architecture in which single instructions can execute several low-level operations (such as a load from memory, an arithmetic operation, and a memory store) or are capable of multi-step operations or addressing modes within single instructions.
A type of metal–oxide–semiconductor field-effect transistor (MOSFET) fabrication process that uses complementary and symmetrical pairs of p-type and n-type MOSFETs for logic functions.
Refers to the bus of a computer that is used by the processor for communicating with several devices connected to it.
Circuitry within a computer's processor that directs operations.
a description of the structure of a computer system made from component parts.
type of optical disc used for data storage and as a platform for multimedia.
A technique in computing in which the computer bus transfers data on both falling and rising edges of a clock cycle/signal at a double rate.
To take out of code and put into understandable language.
A flat, round plate on which data can be encoded and stored.
A method that allows an input/output (I/O) device to send or receive data directly to or from the main memory, bypassing the CPU to speed up memory operations.
a type of random-access memory that stores each bit of data in a separate capacitor within an integrated circuit and which must be periodically refreshed to retain the stored data.
a combination of computer hardware and software designed for a specific function. eg: Motherboard, Panel PCs.
It can be erased and reprogrammed (written to) repeatedly by applying an electrical voltage that is higher than normal.
Form of computer memory that does not lose its content when the power supply is cut off and that can be erased and reused.
The process by which a computer or virtual machine reads and acts on the instructions of a computer program.
a type of non volatile computer storage chip that can be electrically erased and reprogrammed.
a data storage medium that is composed of a disk of thin, flexible magnetic storage medium encased in a square or rectangular plastic shell.
a device for reading floppy disks.
a device that performs basic logical functions that are fundamental to digital circuits.
a specialized electronic circuit initially designed to accelerate computer graphics and image processing.
a non-volatile storage device that stores data on rapidly rotating rigid platters with magnetic surfaces.
A piece of metal that sits on top of a computer chip such as a CPU and draws power away from components by letting it rise through a series of fins.
physical components of a computer.
any peripheral equipment used to provide data and control signals to an information processing system.

An assembly of electronic components in which hundreds to millions of transistors, resistors, and capacitors are interconnected and built up on a thin substrate of semiconductor material (usually silicon) to form a small chip or wafer.
A hardware device that has the ability to accept inputted, outputted or other processed data.

An operating system in which the interrupt system is the mechanism for reporting all changes in the states of hardware and software resources, and such changes are the events that induce new assignments of these resources to meet work-load demands.
A signal sent by a device to an operating system, indicating that it requires immediate attention.
Devices with sensors, processing ability, software and other technologies that connect and exchange data with other devices and systems over the Internet or other communications networks.
A key component of the Central Processing Unit (CPU) in a computer.
an arrangement of buttons or keys to act as mechanical levers or electronic switches.
devices that are used to store data or programs on a temporary or permanent basis for use in an electronic digital computer.
an electronic visual display for computers.
a printed circuit board containing the principal components of a computer or other device, with connectors into which other circuit boards can be slotted.
a pointing device that functions by detecting two-dimensional motion relative to its supporting surface.
A read-only memory whose contents are programmed by the integrated circuit manufacturer (rather than by the user).
The storage of large amounts of data in a persisting and machine-readable fashion.
The first sector of the computer hard drive. It tells the computer how the hard drive is partitioned, and how to load the operating system.
Megahertz one million cycles per second. MHz is used to measure the speed of certain components such as the CPU, GPU and RAM. Higher numbers are faster as more cycles are completed per second.
A transistor family using field-effect transistors. A subset of MOS, Complementary MOS (usually CMOS), built out of paired N-channel and P-channel MOS transistors, is now the most common form.
A standard file format for compressing video images so that they can be stored or sent by email more easily.
memory that can retain the stored data even when not powered.
A computer memory that is able to hold saved data even if there is no power, and does not require periodic refreshes of its memory data.
a disk drive that uses laser light or electromagnetic waves near the light spectrum as part of the process of reading or writing data to or from optical discs.
Any hardware device used to send data from a computer to another device or user.
Peripherals are those devices that connect to the core computer to give it more power and ability.
a device that accepts text and graphic output from a computer and transfers the information to paper.
A piece of hardware that is used to converts the outlet power into usable power to ensure the normal running of parts within a computer.

It is a type of non-volatile computer memory. This means that once data has been written to PROM, it cannot be erased. PROM is used to store programs or firmware for microcontrollers and other digital devices.
any form of computer data storage that allow stored data to be accessed in any order.
a type of memory chip that retains its data when its power supply is switched off.
a storage space for units of memory that are used to transfer data for immediate use by the CPU for data processing.
A microprocessor design that performs fewer computer instructions at higher speeds.
any type of computing hardware that is used for storing, porting or extracting data files and objects.
A serial communication interface through which information transfers in or out sequentially one bit at a time.
A microprocessor architecture that is widely used in high-performance computing and server applications.
A type of random-access memory (RAM) that uses latching circuitry (flip-flop) to store each bit.
An on/off switch and the fundamental building block of computer circuitry.
a flash memory device integrated with a USB interface.
A memory management technique where secondary memory can be used as if it were a part of the main memory.
A series of computers featuring a 32-bit instruction set architecture (ISA) and virtual memory that was developed and sold by Digital Equipment Corporation (DEC) in the late 20th century.
also referred to as a graphics card and several other names, a video card is an expansion card which generates a feed of output images to a display
memory that requires power to maintain the stored information.
a video camera that feeds its images in real time to a computer or computer network, often via USB, Ethernet, or Wi-Fi.
Single strand of metal capable of transmitting power or data from one area to another.
Exclusive OR (XOR, EOR or EXOR) is a logical operator which results true when either of the operands are true (one is true and the other one is false) but both are not true and both are not false.

a subset of computer science that deals with computer systems performing tasks with similar, equal, or superior intelligence to that of a human (e.g. decision-making, object recognition and classification, speech recognition and translation)
also known as strong AI, AGI is a type of artificial intelligence that is considered human-like and still in its preliminary stages (more of a hypothetical existence in the present day).

weak AI, ANI is an artificial intelligence that can only focus on one task or problem at a given time (e.g., playing a game against a human competitor). This is the current existing form of AI. This artificial intelligence algorithm is programmed to solve a limited number of data problems.
a network modeled after the human brain by creating an artificial neural system via a pattern-recognizing computer algorithm that learns from, interprets, and classifies sensory data.

It is the main calculative layer of a neural network. The activation function triggers the right decision node within the neural network and displays the node as an output. It converts a series of inputs into singular or multiple output classes.
A method of manipulating AI models by subtly altering input data to cause incorrect predictions.
Self-drive cars that work on the principle of computer vision to detect, identify, and categorize external obstacles and drive right around them.
A step-by-step procedure for solving a problem or accomplishing a task.
The process of identifying abnormal patterns in data.
A method in neural networks that enables the model to focus on certain parts of the input sequence.
A neural network used for dimensionality reduction and data compression.
Enhancing the real world with computer-generated perceptual information.
Symmetric key algorithm used to encrypt and decrypt data.
The application of machine learning, natural language processing (NLP), and other AI-guided techniques to automatically classify text in a faster, more cost-effective, and more accurate manner.
An algorithm used in training neural networks, where the error is propagated backward to adjust weights.
A probabilistic graphical model that represents a set of variables and their conditional dependencies.
A systematic error introduced by an algorithm when it consistently makes predictions that are off in one direction.
The presence of systematic and unfair prejudice in AI predictions, often due to biased data or models.
The number of training examples processed before the model’s internal parameters are updated.
An AI-based program designed to simulate conversation with human users.
A task of predicting a discrete label (e.g., spam vs. not spam).
A type of unsupervised learning that groups data points with similar characteristics.
A field of AI that trains machines to interpret and understand visual data from the world.
A deep learning model commonly used for analyzing visual imagery.
Techniques used to artificially expand the size of a training dataset by applying transformations.
A tree-like model used for making decisions or predictions based on input data.
A specialized subset of ML that uses neural networks with many layers to analyze data.
Reducing the number of features or input variables in a dataset.
A model that learns the boundary between classes in the training data.
A regularization technique where some neurons are randomly turned off during training.
One complete cycle through the training dataset.
The development of AI systems that respect privacy, fairness, transparency, and accountability.
The process of analyzing datasets to summarize their main characteristics, often with visual methods.
AI systems designed to provide transparent and interpretable explanations for their decisions.
A technology used to identify or verify individuals by their facial features.
Ensuring that AI systems do not produce biased or discriminatory outcomes.
The process of identifying and selecting useful features from raw data.
A model’s ability to learn from a very small amount of data.
Using AI to detect potentially fraudulent activities in financial transactions.
a model involves developers training it further on a specific set of data to improve its performance for a specific application
highly capable general-purpose AI models that can perform a wide variety of tasks and match or exceed the capabilities present in today’s most advanced models
AI systems designed to play video games either as opponents or partners.
A type of model that consists of two neural networks (generator and discriminator) competing with each other to generate realistic data.
A model that generates new data points based on the patterns learned from training data.
A theoretical AI system that can perform any intellectual task that a human can.
An optimization algorithm used to minimize the error in a model by adjusting weights.
similiar to central processing units, but its main function is to accelerate computer graphics and image processing.
Applications of AI in medicine, such as diagnosing diseases, predicting outcomes, and personalizing treatments.
AI systems that rely on human feedback and intervention at key stages of decision-making.
External parameters set before training a model, such as learning rate or number of layers.
large language models generate plausible sounding but inaccurate text and that calls hallucination effect.
A computer vision task where an image is divided into parts that correspond to different objects or regions.
A simple ML algorithm that classifies data points based on their proximity to neighbors.
A lower-dimensional space where data is represented after compression, typically by an autoencoder.
A type of RNN designed to avoid long-term dependency problems.
A subset of AI that enables systems to automatically learn and improve from experience without being explicitly programmed.
A branch of AI focused on enabling machines to understand, interpret, and respond to human language.
A computational model inspired by the human brain, consisting of layers of interconnected nodes
AI that just capables of dealling with some specific tasks.
the underlying code used to run AI models is freely available for testing, scrutiny and improvement
A computer vision task that involves identifying objects in an image or video.
The technology that converts different types of documents, such as scanned paper documents or PDFs, into editable and searchable data
When a model learns the training data too well, including noise and outliers, leading to poor performance on new data.
AI systems that adjust their output based on user preferences and behaviors.
Estimating the position of a person or object in a given image or video.
Using AI to predict when equipment might fail based on data from sensors and historical performance.
An ensemble learning method that combines multiple decision trees to improve accuracy.
A type of neural network where connections form directed cycles, useful for sequential data.
A type of ML where an agent learns by interacting with its environment and receiving feedback in the form of rewards or penalties.
Techniques used to reduce overfitting by penalizing complexity in the model.
A task of predicting a continuous value (e.g., predicting house prices).
The branch of AI that deals with the design and operation of robots.
The use of NLP to determine the sentiment expressed in a piece of text.
Using AI to automate household functions like lighting, security, and temperature control.
AI that generates human-like speech from text.
Converting spoken words into written text using AI.
A type of ML where the model is trained on labeled data.
A supervised learning algorithm used for classification and regression tasks.
A theoretical form of AI that has intelligence greater than humans and exceeds their cognitive performance in most domains
Data used to evaluate the performance of a trained model.
Converting written text into spoken voice using AI.
Data used to teach an AI or ML model.
A technique where a model trained on one task is reused or fine-tuned for another task.
A neural network architecture primarily used for processing sequential data like language.
When a model is too simple and fails to capture the patterns in the data, leading to poor performance.
A type of ML where the model is trained on unlabeled data to identify patterns.
Data used to fine-tune a model during training.
The model’s sensitivity to small changes in the training dataset.
An AI system designed to assist users by answering questions, scheduling tasks, and more (e.g., Siri, Alexa).
An immersive experience created by computer-generated simulations of environments.
The parameter within a machine learning model that transforms input data within the model's architecture.
A representation of words in a continuous vector space where words with similar meanings are close together.
A classic problem in neural networks that is not linearly separable and showcases the need for non-linear activation functions.
A real-time object detection system that divides images into grids and predicts bounding boxes for object detection.
A model’s ability to classify data from categories it has never seen before.
Mechanisms that regulate who can view or use resources in a computing environment.
Unique identifier for a specific computer or device on a network.
User with full control over a network or individual computer.
Protocol used to map an IP address to a physical address, such as a MAC address.
A set of rules that controls traffic in and out of a network or individual device.

A technique of intelligent, fuzzy neural networks or rule-based machine learning systems used for the vernacular immune system. The logic is built using reactive expressions to solve a particular problem, just like the immune system.
A device that allows wireless devices to connect to a wired network.
a network modeled after the human brain by creating an artificial neural system via a pattern-recognizing computer algorithm that learns from, interprets, and classifies sensory data.
Protocol for mapping an Internet Protocol address (IP address) to a physical machine address that is recognized in the local network.
A decentralized wireless network where devices communicate directly without pre-existing infrastructure.
The top layer in the OSI model, responsible for network services like email, file transfer, and web browsing.
The use of AI to optimize and manage network resources dynamically.
The application of AI in identifying and responding to cyber threats in real-time.
The use of AI techniques to detect unusual patterns in network traffic that may indicate security breaches.
The maximum rate of data transfer across a network, typically measured in bits per second (bps).
A wireless technology standard for exchanging data over short distances using radio waves.
A device that connects and filters traffic between two or more network segments to reduce network collisions.
The transmission of a message to all devices on a network.
The use of AI algorithms to allocate network bandwidth efficiently.
AI methods that detect networks of compromised devices used in coordinated cyberattacks.
A networking architecture where client devices request services and resources from a central server.
A network segment where data packets can collide, potentially leading to transmission errors.
A type of neural network often used in AI for image recognition and classification.
The second layer in the OSI model responsible for node-to-node data transfer and error detection/correction.
A system that translates human-friendly domain names into IP addresses.
A network protocol that automatically assigns IP addresses to devices.
A network architecture without a central authority, where decisions and resources are distributed.
A method of examining the content of data packets to detect malicious activity.
An attack that floods a network with traffic to overwhelm its capacity and prevent legitimate use.
A common wired networking technology used in LANs (Local Area Networks).
A network architecture where computation is performed at or near the data source, reducing latency
The process of converting data into a coded format to protect it from unauthorized access.
A firewall that uses AI to automatically adjust its rules and detect sophisticated threats.
A network security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on security rules.
A unit of data that includes addressing information used for transmission at the Data Link layer.
A machine learning approach where the model is trained across multiple decentralized devices using local data.
A type of neural network where connections do not form cycles, used for supervised learning tasks
An extension of cloud computing that brings computational resources closer to the network edge to support real-time applications.
A device that connects two different networks, often translating data between different protocols.
A neural network model that consists of two networks (generator and discriminator) competing to generate realistic data.
A network device that connects multiple devices and sends the received signal to all connected devices.
A type of recurrent neural network used for associative memory tasks in AI.
A network combining multiple types of neural architectures for better performance across different tasks.
A communication protocol for routing data across network boundaries, forming the backbone of the internet.
A network of physical devices embedded with sensors, software, and other technologies that communicate over the internet.
A unique identifier for a device on a network, used for routing data.
A system that monitors network traffic for suspicious activity or policy violations.
A system that detects and prevents potential threats in network traffic.
The time it takes for a packet of data to travel from the source to the destination.
A network that connects computers within a limited area, like a home, office, or building.
AI techniques used to minimize network delays in critical applications like autonomous driving.
A hardware identification number that uniquely identifies each device on a network.
A type of network where devices (nodes) are interconnected and can relay data to one another.
A network that spans a city or a large campus.
A technique that combines multiple signals or data streams into one for transmission.
The use of AI to identify and classify malicious software in network traffic or files.
A cyberattack where the attacker intercepts and possibly alters communication between two parties.
A method that allows multiple devices on a local network to share a single public IP address.
A hardware component that connects a computer to a network.
The third layer in the OSI model responsible for routing data across networks.
The use of AI to analyze and predict network traffic patterns to optimize performance and security.
An AI method to automatically discover the best neural network architectures for a given task.
A method of data transmission where data is broken into packets and transmitted over various routes.
A firewall technique that controls network access by analyzing incoming and outgoing packets.
A network where devices communicate directly with each other without a central server.
The first layer in the OSI model responsible for the physical connection between devices, such as cables and switches.
A technique used to allow external devices to connect to a specific device within a private network.
A set of rules governing data communication between devices on a network.
A server that acts as an intermediary between a client and the internet to enhance security or control internet traffic.
A method of evaluating network security by simulating cyberattacks.
AI-based systems designed to detect and block phishing attacks in email or web traffic.
A device that forwards data packets between networks, often connecting local networks to the internet.
A type of neural network used in AI that processes sequences of data with temporal dependencies.
Using AI techniques to optimize network performance by continuously learning from network behaviors.
The fifth layer in the OSI model, responsible for managing and controlling the connections between computers.
A protocol used for managing and monitoring network devices.
A number that divides an IP address into network and host portions, defining a network's scope.
A network device that connects multiple devices and directs data only to the device it is intended for.
A network that uses AI algorithms to automatically configure and optimize its parameters based on changing conditions.
The use of AI in SDN to manage and automate network functions dynamically.
A type of neural network that models biological neurons more closely, used in AI for processing temporal data.
A type of attack where the attacker disguises themselves as another entity to gain unauthorized access.
Protocols used to secure communications over a network.
The collective behavior of decentralized, self-organized systems, often applied in AI to solve network problems.
A suite of communication protocols used to interconnect network devices on the internet.
A method of transmitting multiple signals over a single communication channel by dividing them into time slots.
A connection-oriented protocol that ensures reliable data transmission over a network.
The use of AI models to predict and manage network congestion by analyzing traffic patterns.
A type of malware that disguises itself as legitimate software to infiltrate a network.
The transmission of data from one device to another specific device on a network.
The use of unsupervised machine learning models to detect anomalies or threats in network traffic.
A logical subdivision of a physical network, enabling the grouping of devices as if they were on the same network.
A secure tunnel through which data can be transmitted over the internet as if it were on a private network.
A technology that allows voice communication to occur over the internet rather than traditional phone lines.
A network that extends over a large geographical area, connecting LANs and other networks.
A technology that allows wireless devices to connect to the internet or a network using radio waves.
A type of malware that replicates itself to spread to other computers on a network.
A security model that assumes no implicit trust in network users, where AI continuously verifies each access attempt.
